n't come across as Capitol Hill's biggest fan. Google is a tech company that loves facts, metrics and algorithms, after all. Eric Schmidt might prefer a political system that dealt in such quantities. I spend so much time in Washington now because of the work that I've been doing, I deal with all these people who make assertions without fact, he said. offerings. Stephen Elop , a defector from Redmond, and Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer jointly released a statement on the rebel alliance against the growing Android presence in the smart phone market. The statement read: Nokia will adopt Windows Phone as its primary smartphone strategy, innovating on top of the platform in areas such as imaging, where Nokia is a market leader. Stephen Elop implied, in a separate interview, that together Microsoft and Nokia would be able to level the playing field with the exponentially growing Android contingent, as well as high-end smart phone leaders Apple.

n't heard: Did Eric Schmidt jump ship, or was he forced to walk the plank? He Jumped Eric Schmidt has "career aspirations outside of Google," says Bianca Bosker at The Huffington Post. Some speculate Eric Schmidt will remain executive chairman only temporarily before pursuing a career in the public sector, a field in which he has previously demonstrated interest. the incident reflects a new, more reactive attitude toward slights emanating from Larry Page, the Google co-founder who will become CEO in April and is considered more volatile and less diplomatic than outgoing CEO Eric Schmidt . Google's complaint is the height of hypocrisy. The company's entire business model is built on the use of other people's content usually without bothering to seek permission, said John Simpson, from Consumer Watchdog's Inside Google research team. Google's allegations are an attempt to make Microsoft look bad for doing what every search provider does constantly: analyze competitors' search engines
